text: hi my name is sohaib katariwala and I am
an analytics specialist Essay with AWS
today I will show you how you can
simplify data loading into Amazon
redshift with the Amazon redshift query
editor V2
I will start by opening up query editor
V2 in my AWS console
when you open up
query editor V2 for the first time in
your account for a given region you will
see the configure account screen
here you can optionally customize
encryption
and you can specify an S3 location that
can be used for features such as data
loading from a local file store
the S3 bucket used here must be
configured with a proper permissions to
secure user data here is an example of
the IAM policy attached to the AWS users
or roles that I will be using to load
data from a local file store using query
editor V2 for more information on the
recommended permissions to apply to this
S3 bucket see the link in the
description below I have already created
an S3 bucket with a proper permissions
that I will use
I will then click on configure account
now my account is configured and I am
ready to use Query editor V2
if I did not specify an S3 bucket during
the initial configure account screen I
can still do that at any time using the
account settings
I can also use account settings to
change the S3 bucket location
I will click on account settings
and here I can see a few different
settings for query editor V2 that I can
set such as the max concurrent sessions
the ability to export result sets and to
set or edit the S3 bucket path
I have a CSV file in my local file store
that I want to load into my redshift
workgroup
here is my CSV file it is called
supplier 5000 rows.csv
let's open it up and see what the data
in the file looks like
I have seven columns in this file and I
have a header row as well
when I scroll down to the bottom of the
file
I can see that there are a total of 5
000 rows in this file
I will connect to my redshift serverless
work group
then I will click on the create button
followed by table to create a table
where I want to load data into
when I do that I get a pop-up window
that asks me to select the schema that
my new table will be created under as
well as the name I want to give to my
new table
I will name my table supplier
next I will need to define the columns
for this table
I can either add columns manually or I
can have the query editor automatically
infer The Columns by reading the CSV
file
to do this I will click on the load from
CSV button and click on browse in the
pop-up to select the CSV file on my
local system that I showed you earlier
when I do that I can immediately see
that the columns were automatically
populated based on the file the column
names were selected from the header Row
in the file and the data types were also
inferred based on a sample of the data
in the CSV file
I now have the option to make any
changes as an example I will change the
supplier key from an integer data type
to bigint
I can also change column encoding the
default values
null ability
and size of the fields
I can also specify certain columns as
key constraints
when I'm satisfied I can either create
the table directly by clicking on create
table
or I can
open the create table command in the
query Editor to make any final
adjustments
I will select the open inquiry editor
option and that opens a new tab in the
query editor with the create table
command in it the code looks good so I
will run this query to create the table
now that the create table command has
completed I will run a simple query to
verify that the table does exist
as you can see the query runs
successfully but does not return any
rows
this is because I only created the table
but I did not load data into it yet
to load data into this table I will
click on the load data button when I
click that I can see two options
I can either load data from S3 or load
from a local file
the load from a local file option allows
you to load data from a local file that
is up to five megabytes in size
the load data from S3 option allows you
to load data from files of any size in
Amazon S3
for this demo I will show you both of
these methods once I click on load from
local file I can browse for local files
I will find and select the supplier CSV
file that I showed you earlier and click
on open
now I can specify certain file options
such as the delimiter character the
quill character and encryption
I can select the compression options if
my file is compressed
in this case my CSV file is uncompressed
I can select the data conversion
parameters such as how to handle invalid
characters the time format whether or
not to truncate data in columns the
number of header rows in the file and
many other parameters
in this case I do have a header Row in
my CSV file so I will check the box for
ignore header rows and select one as the
number of header rows to ignore
I then click on done to save that
setting I can also select certain load
options for advanced load settings such
as the number of rows to use for
redshift table compression analysis and
other optional load operations
in this case the default settings will
work just fine so I will leave them as
is now I will specify which table I want
to load this data into
I will select the supplier table I
created earlier in the public schema
then I will click on load data now the
redshift query editor will load the data
from my CSV file into my redshift table
once the data load is complete
I will see a banner appear on my screen
that says loading data from a local file
succeeded I can close that banner and
click done
now I will rerun the same query I ran
earlier to select star from the supplier
table
I can now see that there are indeed rows
in this table that match what is in my
local CSV file
I will also run another query to count
how many rows are in the supplier table
I can see from the result that there are
indeed five thousand rows in my supplier
table which matches how many rows there
are in my local CSV file now we have
seen how to load data from a local file
what if I wanted to load data from a
file or a set of files that were located
in Amazon S3
I can load from S3 also
I again start by clicking on the load
data button and then select load from S3
I can now browse S3 for our file path
here I select the bucket and any
subfolder that contains my file or the
specific file itself
once I've selected the file to load I
can specify the file format you can see
here that there are many different file
formats that are supported
since my file in Amazon S3 is a parquet
file I will select parquet as the file
format
just like with load from local file
option I can specify file options
compression options and load options
then I select the table which I want to
load this data into
in this case I'll select a table I've
already created called supplier 2.
this option I also need to select an IAM
role this drop down will list all IM
rules that are attached to my redshift
namespace or my redshift cluster
here I want to select the IEM rule that
has permissions to read the files in S3
that I'm trying to load into my redshift
table
now I will click on load data
I can see the copy command that is
automatically generated is running in a
new query editor tab
now that the copy command has completed
I can run a query to count how many rows
are loaded into the supplier 2 table
I can confirm that the data from the
parquet file in S3 was loaded into my
target table
in summary I showed you how you can
create a table in redshift from a local
CSV file how you can load the data from
the local CSV file into a redshift table
and how you can also load data from an
Amazon S3 location into a redshift table
all using the redshift query editor V2
thank you so much for watching this
video
